title-group.article-title: Which type of job mobility makes people happy? A comparative analysis of European welfare regimes

abstract.p: In view of changing job mobility patterns in Europe, the impact of job mobility on job satisfaction is gaining importance, yet has received little attention. This article analyses 23 European countries to address two questions: (1) how do different types of job mobility affect job satisfaction, and (2) do welfare state regimes alter the relationship between job mobility and job satisfaction? Theoretically the study integrates economic and sociological approaches to job satisfaction with insights from the psychology of well-being. The findings show that job mobility differentially affects job satisfaction domains. External upward mobility is decisive to enhance satisfaction with objective working conditions and work–life balance, while internal mobility is pivotal for satisfaction with future career prospects. The experience of unemployment lowers all job satisfaction domains even after re-employment. The article’s findings on welfare regimes indicate that social policies interact with country differences in workforce composition, such as the overall prevalence of unemployment, to determine job satisfaction.

trans-abstract.title: Résumé
trans-abstract.p: Compte tenu des changements dans les modalités de la mobilité professionnelle en Europe, l’impact de la mobilité professionnelle sur la satisfaction au travail se révèle de plus en plus important, et pourtant ce sujet a jusqu’à présent peu retenu l’attention. Dans cet article, 23 pays européens sont analysés afin d’essayer de répondre à deux questions : (1) de quelle manière différents types de mobilité professionnelle influent-ils sur la satisfaction au travail ? et (2) les régimes de protection sociale modifient-ils le rapport entre mobilité professionnelle et satisfaction au travail ? Au plan théorique, cette étude réalise une synthèse entre les approches économique et sociologique de la satisfaction au travail et celles relatives à la psychologie du bien-être. Les résultats indiquent que la mobilité professionnelle affecte de différentes manières chaque domaine de la satisfaction au travail. La mobilité externe ascendante est décisive pour accroître le niveau de satisfaction concernant les conditions objectives de travail et l’équilibre entre vie professionnelle et vie privée, tandis que la mobilité interne joue un rôle essentiel dans la satisfaction concernant les perspectives de carrière. L’expérience du chômage réduit l’ensemble des domaines de satisfaction, même après avoir retrouvé un emploi. Les conclusions de l’article sur les régimes de protection sociale montrent que les politiques sociales et les différences dans la structure du marché du travail de chaque pays, telles que la prédominance absolue du chômage, s’influencent mutuellement pour déterminer le degré de satisfaction au travail.

trans-abstract.title: Resumen
trans-abstract.p: El impacto de la movilidad laboral sobre la satisfacción con el trabajo está ganando importancia a la vista de los cambios en las pautas de movilidad laboral en Europa, aunque todavía ha recibido escasa atención. Este artículo analiza 23 países europeos para responder a dos cuestiones: (1), ¿cómo afectan diferentes tipos de movilidad laboral a la satisfacción laboral?, y (2) ¿afectan los regímenes de estado del bienestar a la relación entre movilidad laboral y satisfacción con el trabajo? A nivel teórico, el estudio integra los enfoques económicos y sociológicos sobre la satisfacción con el trabajo con aportaciones de la psicología del bienestar. Los resultados muestran que la movilidad laboral afecta de forma diferente a cada ámbito de la satisfacción con el trabajo. La movilidad externa ascendente es decisiva para incrementar la satisfacción con las condiciones objetivas de trabajo y la conciliación entre el trabajo y la vida privada, mientras que la movilidad interna es esencial para las expectativas de carrera futura. La experiencia del desempleo reduce la satisfacción en todos los ámbitos, incluso después de la encontrar un nuevo empleo. Los resultados del artículo sobre los regímenes de bienestar indican que las políticas sociales interactúan con las características de la composición de la fuerza de trabajo de cada país, tales como la prevalencia total del desempleo, en la determinación de la satisfacción con el trabajo.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In view of changing labor market careers (Spilerman, 2009) and an increasing emphasis on the ‘soft’ outcomes of labor market processes, the impact of job mobility on job satisfaction is gaining importance, yet has received little attention. Subjective or ‘soft’ outcomes of labor market processes have recently drawn increasing attention across disciplines, e.g. in economics (Frey and Stutzer, 2002a; Layard, 2005), the psychology of well-being (Diener and Oishi, 2005) and social inequality research (Delhey and Kohler, 2006). Job satisfaction is a subjective outcome of experienced labor market mobility. The present study contributes to the literature by addressing two questions: (1) are there ‘net job mobility effects’ on job satisfaction beyond changing job rewards and (2) how do they vary across welfare state regimes?

We extend previous research by integrating economic and sociological theories on job mobility and job satisfaction with insights from the psychology of well-being. We use an abbreviated retrospective life course questionnaire (Brückner and Mayer, 1998; Mayer and Brückner, 1989; Reimer, 2004) on job mobility as part of the Eurobarometer (64.1)1 to allow a retrospective reconstruction of important markers of job mobility. By using retrospectively collected job mobility information, our analysis ensures temporal precedence of job mobility events before the reporting of job satisfaction (Blossfeld and Pötter, 2001). Thus, our approach overcomes shortcomings of purely cross-sectional analyses.

European welfare states differ in levels of job mobility (DiPrete et al., 1997), policies that restrict or facilitate mobility (Schmid et al., 1996), general job satisfaction levels (Sousa-Poza and Sousa-Poza, 2000) and enduringly negative effects of unemployment (Gallie and Paugam, 2000). As a consequence, job mobility can have differential effects on subsequent job satisfaction across welfare regimes. While welfare state differences in terms of employees’ job preferences (Gallie, 2007) and work orientations (Hult and Svallfors, 2002) have recently drawn increasing attention, comparative studies on job satisfaction are scarce (for exceptions see Origo and Pagani, 2009; Sousa-Poza and Sousa-Poza, 2000). We adopt a comparative perspective across six European welfare regimes, distinguishing between a corporatist, liberal, social-democratic, Southern, Central and Eastern European (CEE) and Baltic welfare regime (Blossfeld et al., 2006). Drawing on the literature on long-term non-pecuniary costs of unemployment (e.g. Kassenböhmer and Haisken-De New, 2009), we focus on the impact of unemployment on subsequent job satisfaction by welfare state regimes. Long-term non-pecuniary costs of unemployment are particularly relevant given an increase in unemployment in the wake of the current financial crisis and economic recession.

Our findings support the conclusion that job mobility differentially affects domain-specific job satisfaction: external mobility is decisive for satisfaction with objective working conditions, such as work contract, and for satisfaction with work–life balance. In contrast, internal mobility is more powerful in predicting satisfaction with future career prospects. Unemployment lowers satisfaction on all job satisfaction domains, even after re-employment. In addition, welfare regime differences spur their own dynamics into the processes that determine job satisfaction. Satisfaction with work contract is notably lower in the Southern and Baltic countries that combine rigid insider–outsider labor markets with a relatively high proportion of workers located outside the core protected workforce. Unemployment is least detrimental in liberal countries with internal labor markets, in which unemployment is overall more prevalent but usually of shorter duration, and thus may be less socially stigmatized.

sec.title: Previous research
sec.p: There is extensive sociological and economic research on both job mobility and job satisfaction but they are rarely examined in connection with each other. On the one hand, studies on the consequences of job mobility largely focus on objective rather than subjective outcomes, e.g. earnings growth (Hannan et al., 1990; Le Grand and Tåhlin, 2002). Job satisfaction, on the other hand, is mostly analysed as an outcome of situational characteristics of the workplace (Salancik and Pfeffer, 1978), individual differences in attitudes and values (Kalleberg, 1977), or social comparisons to relevant others (Clark and Oswald, 1996). The following studies on the impact of job mobility on subsequent job satisfaction are mostly limited to specific types of job mobility and single sub-domains of job satisfaction (e.g. satisfaction with salary), and tend to be based on small samples within single organizations or specific sub-groups (e.g. younger workers; Van der Velde and Feij, 1995).

Findings on the impact of unemployment on overall life satisfaction and job satisfaction after re-employment are inconclusive. A number of studies find that unemployment enduringly lowers overall subjective well-being (Andersen, 2009; Kassenböhmer and Haisken-De New, 2009; Winkelmann and Winkelmann, 1998). Lucas et al. (2004) report that persons who experience unemployment on average never completely return to their former level of life satisfaction over a time span of 15 years, even after re-employment. Repeated unemployment phases have even been shown to create a downward spiral of unhappiness (Luhmann and Eid, 2009). In contrast, Kalleberg and Mastekaasa (2001) found that layoffs had no impact on job satisfaction after re-employment, but lowered organizational commitment in the new job. Their analysis is based on a Norwegian sample, and might reflect a country-specific effect related to high levels of unemployment compensation and active labor market policies in Norway.

Studies consistently find that voluntary job changes increase job satisfaction (Bartel and Borjas, 1981; Gottschalk and Maloney, 1985; Kalleberg and Mastekaasa, 2001; Van der Velde and Feij, 1995). There is some indication that current jobs are evaluated in a temporal comparison with the past; persons who feel they are worse-off financially than they were a year ago report significantly lower pay satisfaction (Sweeney et al., 1990). The impact of job mobility on job satisfaction has further been discussed in relation to age, since the time span in which people can change jobs naturally increases with age, even though mobility tends to be most frequent in early careers. Research mostly supports a positive relationship between age and job satisfaction (Janson and Martin, 1982; Kalleberg and Loscocco, 1983; Warr, 1992). Kalleberg and Mastekaasa (2001) point out the importance of controlling for the mediating effect of improved job rewards following job changes. While a positive impact of upward moves and voluntary job changes wanes after controlling for changes in objective job rewards, they find a negative impact of downward and lateral mobility on job satisfaction that is virtually unaffected by current job rewards (Kalleberg and Mastekaasa, 2001: 199).

Concerning cross-national differences in job satisfaction levels, evidence based on ISSP data2 suggests that job satisfaction is high in social-democratic countries, particularly in Denmark, intermediate in conservative and liberal regimes and comparatively lower in Southern and post-socialist countries, with the lowest levels found in Hungary (Sousa-Poza and Sousa-Poza, 2000). Previous research on the impact of welfare regime variation in life satisfaction is inconclusive and has not supported a substantial effect of welfare regimes (Lapinski et al., 1998).

Overall, the consequences of job mobility for job satisfaction have received little attention and existing research is rather fragmented. We contribute to the literature by examining several sub-domains of job satisfaction (satisfaction with work contract, satisfaction with career prospects, satisfaction with work–life balance) and different types of job mobility. We analyse 23 European countries3 based on the 2005 special Eurobarometer 64.1 (EB 64.1, 2005), which provides an original opportunity to draw more general conclusions about the relationship between job mobility and job satisfaction under different institutional conditions.

sec.title: Job mobility and job satisfaction
sec.p: We adopt a definition of job satisfaction that includes an affective and a cognitive component defining job satisfaction as ‘an internal state that is expressed by affectively and/or cognitively evaluating an experienced job with some degree of favor or disfavor’ (Brief, 1998: 86). We use a self-reported job satisfaction measure based on a hierarchical scale. Such self-reported satisfaction measures primarily address the cognitive component of job satisfaction (Brief and Weiss, 2002), but are not fully separable from its affective components. There is broad consensus in the literature that objective circumstances alone are poor predictors of satisfaction (Argyle, 1987). Instead, satisfaction is usually conceptualized as the difference between subjective aspirations and objective circumstances. Sufficient difference between an objective state and the desired state leads to dissatisfaction.

Prominent sociological and economic approaches to explain job satisfaction include reference group theory, the job reward hypothesis and the life cycle hypothesis. In reference group theory subjective aspirations are conceptualized as reference levels against which individuals evaluate their own situation, for instance their income or working conditions (Easterlin, 1976, 1995; Stouffer et al., 1949). The key question then is on which grounds individual reference levels are formed. A basic distinction can be made between social comparisons with others (Festinger, 1954; Merton and Kitt, 1950) and temporal self-comparisons (Albert, 1977). Feeling worse-off relative to a comparison group, or compared to a previous situation, will induce a sense of relative deprivation and dissatisfaction. Following reference group theory, relative differences and not objective job rewards will determine job satisfaction.

The job reward hypothesis (Quinn et al., 1974) argues that older workers are more satisfied, because their jobs are better in terms of extrinsic and intrinsic rewards. With age, workers accumulate job tenure, experience and skills that facilitate voluntary job mobility and the attainment of better placements. Higher income is one aspect of upward mobility, but upward mobility also refers to higher prestige and more interesting tasks on the job. In this view, job satisfaction is simply a result of objective job rewards and age is positively related to job satisfaction when paired with upward career mobility. The value-rewards hypothesis (Kalleberg and Mastekaasa, 2001) is in essence a reformulation of the job reward hypothesis that shifts the focus to job mobility instead of age. The main assumption is that job rewards determine job satisfaction but individual characteristics, such as individual work values, play a role as well (Kalleberg and Mastekaasa, 2001: 188). Individual work values are assumed to be relatively stable, thus short-term changes in job satisfaction will mainly result from changes in job rewards. The value-rewards hypothesis predicts that job mobility will induce a change in job satisfaction to the extent that it changes job rewards. Downward moves will lead to lower job satisfaction and upward moves will lead to higher job satisfaction. The job/value-rewards hypothesis assumes that job mobility has no impact on job satisfaction beyond changes in objective job rewards, i.e. there is no ‘net mobility effect’.

The life cycle hypothesis (Campbell et al., 1976; Wilensky, 1981) emphasizes that workers’ requirements of a job change across the life course. When they first enter the labor market, a job that provides for basic material needs and offers some degree of opportunity for advancement may be deemed satisfactory. In later life stages new needs related to family formation arise, such as the acquisition of housing. After children have grown up financial pressures diminish and instead additional requirements are placed on job security and fringe benefits (Kalleberg and Loscocco, 1983). The life cycle approach emphasizes the necessity of examining different domains of job satisfaction separately, since their relative importance for overall job satisfaction will vary over the life course. There may be a trade-off between satisfaction in different domains, e.g. satisfaction with future career prospects and work–life balance.

The psychology of well-being and satisfaction (Brickman and Campbell, 1971; Diener et al., 2006) focuses on processes of adaptation or non-adaptation to changing circumstances. According to adaptation level theory (Brickman and Campbell, 1971; Helson, 1948, 1964), also known as the hedonic treadmill model, individual satisfaction baselines determine people’s satisfaction levels. Positive or negative events can induce a short-term increase or drop in satisfaction, but people will soon adapt back to a neutral state of satisfaction. One of the most controversial implications is that people will always adjust back to a neutral satisfaction level no matter what happens to them and therefore not much can be done to change long-term satisfaction. With regard to job satisfaction, the hedonic treadmill model predicts that job mobility will not have an enduring impact on job satisfaction, since individuals will adapt to a neutral set point soon after changes. In contrast to the job/value-rewards hypothesis, the hedonic treadmill model predicts that satisfaction is stable within individuals, even if job rewards change.

The hedonic treadmill idea relates to the honeymoon-hangover hypothesis of job satisfaction after voluntary job changes (Boswell et al., 2009). According to the honeymoon-hangover hypothesis, low satisfaction will precede a voluntary job change, followed by a sharp increase in job satisfaction immediately after the job change (honeymoon effect). But job satisfaction will go down again as persons adapt with tenure to the new job (hangover effect). In contrast to the hedonic treadmill model, the honeymoon-hangover hypothesis is unspecific about the exact levels of adaptation and assumes that satisfaction levels may not adjust exactly to their former levels on a stable individual set point.

The hedonic treadmill model has been challenged beyond the questionable assumption of full adaptation to stable individual satisfaction set points. Critics call for five revisions of the hedonic treadmill model based on growing empirical counter-evidence (Diener et al., 2006):

list-item.p: Satisfaction set points are not neutral, but tend to be positive. In general, people tend to be happy. This is in line with the stable finding of a tendency toward high reported job satisfaction (Gruenberg, 1980; Kahn, 1972).

Individual set points of satisfaction vary, among others based on personality characteristics. Job satisfaction will vary between persons, regardless of objective circumstances or social comparisons. With regard to job satisfaction, individual work values and the subjective importance people attach to different life domains are important sources of inter-individual differences (Kalleberg, 1977).

There are multiple set points for separate domains of satisfaction that may move in different directions over time (Lucas et al., 1996). This implies that sub-domains of job satisfaction have to be analysed separately, as emphasized in the life cycle hypothesis.

Satisfaction levels can enduringly change after certain life events. Based on a series of studies, Diener and Oishi (2005) propose that social factors, such as lack of respect and trusted friends, can lead to enduring drops in satisfaction, while people tend to fully adjust to smaller changes in life circumstances. Following this rationale, ‘drastic’ career events, such as unemployment, may change set points of satisfaction in the long term, regardless of job rewards, which contradicts the assumption of full adaptation. Related to this is the notion that negative events affect satisfaction more powerfully than positive events (Diener and Oishi, 2005), similar to the phenomenon of ‘loss aversion’ in prospect theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979). Persons react more sensitively to potential losses than to potential gains, because they tend to be risk averse. Consequently, the negative impact of downward job mobility on subsequent satisfaction would be greater than the positive impact of upward mobility throughout the course of a career.

The hedonic treadmill model implies that adaptation is a more or less uniform process. Contrary to this assumption, evidence indicates that baseline levels of satisfaction lead to differential patterns of adaptation or non-adaptation (Diener and Oishi, 2005).

sec.p: The theories discussed in the preceding paragraphs suggest three possible relationships between job mobility and job satisfaction. First, job satisfaction changes to the extent that job rewards change with job mobility. There is no ‘net mobility effect’ on job satisfaction (job/value-rewards hypothesis). Second, people adjust to their situation soon after a job change and return to a steady individual set point of satisfaction, no matter what happens. Job mobility will only lead to short-term changes in job satisfaction, even if job rewards change (hedonic treadmill model). Third, the impact of job mobility on job satisfaction depends on the direction and frequency of job moves and career events. Negative events are more powerful than positive events, and drastic events can enduringly lower set points for satisfaction. Job mobility can have an impact beyond changes in objective job rewards in the form of ‘net mobility effects’ and can differentially affect sub-domains of job satisfaction (revisions of hedonic treadmill model).

In line with evidence from the psychology of well-being, we follow the revisions of the hedonic treadmill model in the specification of our main hypotheses. We assume that the impact of job mobility on job satisfaction will differ by sub-domains of job satisfaction and types of job mobility. We distinguish three groups of job mobility indicators: (1) upward and downward mobility, (2) internal and external job mobility and (3) overall job mobility indicators, such as the number of job moves and periods of unemployment. After specifying our main hypotheses on the impact of job mobility on job satisfaction, we discuss possible variations across welfare regimes.

sec.title: Upward and downward mobility
sec.p: A greater impact of negative than positive events on satisfaction, conceptualized as ‘loss aversion’ in prospect theory, has also been addressed in the framework of reference group theory: upward comparisons, particularly the feeling of relative deprivation, have a greater impact on satisfaction than downward comparisons (e.g. Delhey and Kohler, 2006). In temporal comparison throughout the course of a career, a downward job move will induce an upward comparison to a better job held in the past. Therefore, the negative impact of a downward move will exceed the positive impact of an upward move on job satisfaction. We expect a positive impact of upward mobility with the last job change and a negative impact of downward mobility due to changing job rewards as predicted in the value-rewards hypothesis (Kalleberg and Mastekaasa, 2001). We further hypothesize a ‘net mobility effect’ based on the assumption of loss aversion, after controlling for objective job rewards:
Hypothesis A: The negative effect of downward mobility in the last job change will exceed the positive impact of upward mobility in the last job change on job satisfaction.

sec.title: Internal and external mobility
sec.p: Careers evolve over time, but different aspects of time, such as moves between compared to within firms, have different implications (Rosenfeld, 1992). Internal mobility will most likely be connected to internal seniority criteria, whereas external moves may happen because of a number of firm internal or external reasons, such as layoffs, better external options for career advancement, shifts between occupations, or residential moves of employees to combine work and family. In case of an internal move, both the employer and the employee have better information about the abilities of the worker and the demands of a position, which increases the probability of a good job–employee match (Rosenfeld, 1992: 46). Concerning external moves, applicants and potential employers have to rely more heavily on relatively crude observable signals, such as educational certificates (Spence, 1973; Stiglitz, 1976). Internal upward moves are perceived as the natural progression of a career and thus will not induce higher satisfaction, if they do not exceed expected upward mobility. Internal downward moves will be perceived as a greater loss, since they counter expected seniority ladders. Internal downward moves will induce a feeling of relative deprivation both in a temporal self-comparison with the previous position and with relevant others whose careers follow standard seniority steps. We hypothesize that:
Hypothesis B: The last internal job move will have a larger impact on job satisfaction than the last external job move.

sec.title: Unemployment
sec.p: With the job/value-rewards hypothesis one can argue that scar effects of unemployment (Gangl, 2004) will lead to a selection into lower quality jobs after unemployment that affect job satisfaction negatively through unfavorable job rewards. However, employment is not simply a source of income but a socialization context, a source of social relationships and identity, and a promoter of individual self-esteem (Andersen, 2009; Kassenböhmer and Haisken-De New, 2009; Winkelmann and Winkelmann, 1998). Therefore, unemployment can be considered a ‘drastic’ career event that potentially lowers job satisfaction set points even after re-employment (Fujita and Diener, 2005; Lucas et al., 2004) regardless of objective job rewards (‘net mobility effect’):
Hypothesis C: Job satisfaction decreases with the number of previous unemployment spells.

sec.title: Welfare regimes
sec.p: Countries differ in job mobility levels (DiPrete et al., 1997), national policies and structural factors, such as industry differences, that restrict or facilitate job mobility (Ng et al., 2007; Schmid et al., 1996) and general job satisfaction levels (Sousa-Poza and Sousa-Poza, 2000). Welfare policies and country-specific structural and compositional contexts may thus generate different levels of job satisfaction in response to job mobility. Two important country differences arise from social policies that cluster in ‘welfare regimes’ (Esping-Andersen, 1990) and differences in workforce composition that cluster in ‘employment systems’ through which such policies are refracted (Gallie, 2007). Based on an analysis of Denmark, Finland, Germany, Great Britain and Sweden, Gallie (2007) argues that country differences in workforce composition are more important for employees’ job preference orientations than welfare regimes. While job preference orientations and job satisfaction both refer to subjective expectations and evaluations of work, they are conceptually distinct and their institutional determinants must not necessarily coincide. For our analysis of job satisfaction the following country compositional differences are particularly relevant: general workforce composition, for instance in terms of permanent and temporary employment, the overall prevalence of job mobility and the frequency and duration of unemployment.

The compositional differences reflected in employment systems only partly overlap with welfare regimes (Gallie, 2007). Our empirical analyses are based on a country classification that derives primarily from the welfare regime literature because it offers a more established classification for the 23 countries we study. Throughout, we discuss compositional differences reflected in employment systems for each welfare regime and argue that the combination of social policies and compositional country differences is decisive for job satisfaction.

Despite the unavoidable ambiguity of any welfare regime classification, welfare regime typologies remain a useful heuristic for identifying broad differences across European countries. Empirically, life course outcomes cluster in welfare regimes to a considerable extent (e.g. Mayer, 2001). We follow the extended welfare state regime classification put forward by Blossfeld and co-authors (Blossfeld and Hofmeister, 2006; Blossfeld et al., 2006; Buchholz et al., 2009) that extends the three worlds of social-democratic, liberal and corporatist welfare regimes proposed by Esping-Andersen (1990) with a broadly accepted Southern welfare regime (Esping-Andersen, 1999; Ferreira, 2008; Ferrera, 1996) and a less established post-socialist type. We additionally divide the post-socialist type into the CEE and Baltic countries (Saar et al., 2010). Our country classification is presented in Table 1.

sec.p: With regard to structural labor market differences, several classifications place countries on a continuum between two extremes that pertain to similar differences: coordinated vs liberal market economies (Hall and Soskice, 2001), collectivist vs individualist mobility regimes (DiPrete et al., 1997), closed vs open employment relationships (Blossfeld et al., 2006) and occupational labor markets (OLMs) vs internal labor markets (ILMs) (Gangl, 2001; Marsden, 1999). Classification of countries into OLMs and ILMs, particularly for the CEE and Baltic transition economies is uncertain. Research suggests that they may be more appropriately thought of as a continuum, rather than a dichotomous typology (Saar et al., 2010).

In labor markets with open employment relationships, which tend to overlap with ILMs, job security is low, labor market flexibility is high and individual human capital resources are particularly important for mobility. Unemployment is relatively frequent but often only short-term with a generally higher rate of job mobility. Characteristic for ILMs are generalized education systems that do not provide occupation-specific skills. Firms therefore tend to hire internally and internal mobility plays a key role for career advancement. Occupational segmentation of the labor market is low.

In labor markets with closed employment relationships, which tend to overlap with OLMs, individual human capital resources are less decisive for mobility (DiPrete et al., 1997). Unemployment is generally of longer duration, and the rate of job mobility is lower than in labor markets with open employment relationships (Blossfeld et al., 2006). Precarious employment forms are concentrated among marginalized groups, such as labor market entrants, women, or low-skilled workers. Education systems in OLMs provide occupation-specific skills that are transferrable between employers. Firms therefore tend to hire externally within industries. This leads to strong occupational segmentation. Both job mobility and job insecurity tend to be higher in ILMs than in OLMs, with stronger employment protection legislation (EPL) in OLMs.

Liberal market economies strongly overlap with open employment relationships and strong ILMs. Protective labor market factors, such as active labor market policies, labor unions and job security legislation, are weak. Mobility levels are relatively high and unemployment occurs frequently but usually only for short durations. Social-democratic countries are characterized by relatively closed employment relationships and strong labor unions. Active labor market policies are extensive and taxation policies are aimed at full employment. In the corporatist regime, employment relationships are equally closed and powerful unions render layoffs difficult and costly. They tend to have strong OLMs and extensive EPL. Labor markets are subject to strong insider–outsider segmentation (Doeringer and Piore, 1971). Employment and job mobility are promoted to a lesser degree than in the social-democratic countries, but extensive protection is provided for workers who leave employment due to job loss, disability, or retirement. The Southern welfare regime is also characterized by segmented insider–outsider labor markets with a relatively high prevalence of precarious temporary employment located outside the core protected workforce (Golsch, 2003). The Southern countries are highly family oriented. Family and kinship networks to a certain extent compensate for weak active labor market and welfare sustaining policies, which resemble the liberal residual type of sub-protective unemployment provision (Esping-Andersen, 1990; Ferrera, 1996; Gallie and Paugam, 2000).

The classification of post-socialist countries remains controversial (Esping-Andersen, 1999; Ferrera, 1996). Nevertheless, several common characteristics mark the post-socialist countries in contrast to western welfare states. Labor markets rapidly shifted from closed toward open employment systems with the collapse of socialist communism (Deacon, 1992, 2000; Novak, 2001). Recent reforms mark a radical break from the comprehensive social security policy under socialism. Welfare coverage remains relatively broad but benefit levels are generally low (Blossfeld et al., 2006). Unemployment, previously practically non-existent in these countries, sharply increased during the turbulences of the transition process. With the economic transition, skills acquired under socialism often became less marketable, which has increased career uncertainty (Standing, 1996). Despite these general tendencies in post-socialist transition economies, they are quite heterogeneous with pronounced differences between the CEE and the Baltic countries. Overall, the CEE countries tend to have weaker EPL combined with more open employment relationships than the Baltic countries. In the Baltic countries a stronger insider–outsider segmentation is combined with more extensive EPL, which is however often only weakly and selectively enforced (Cazes and Nesporova, 2004; Delhey and Newton, 2005).4 Given the early stage of research on post-socialist welfare regimes, the inclusion of these countries is a specific strength of our analysis.

sec.title: Welfare regimes and unemployment
sec.p: Overall, we expect job satisfaction to be highest in the social-democratic countries due to high employment protection combined with active labor market policies that foster high-quality job mobility. If other European countries function as reference frames, job satisfaction, particularly with objective working conditions and career prospects, will be lower in post-socialist countries, because western countries provide higher benefit levels in case of job loss, as well as generally higher labor market stability and predictability compared to the post-socialist transition economies (Saar et al., 2010).

We assume that hypothesis C, on the negative relationship between unemployment and job satisfaction, will be less pronounced in the social-democratic welfare regime. The more advanced safety nets paired with active labor market policies that foster re-employment, summarized as ‘flexicurity’, should dampen the scar effects of unemployment (Delhey and Kohler, 2006). The same could be true for the greater flexibility and on average shorter duration of unemployment in open employment relationships that are prevalent in the liberal welfare regime and the CEE transition countries.

The negative effect of unemployment on job satisfaction will be higher in corporatist and Southern welfare regimes, as well as the Baltic countries, due to rigid insider–outsider labor markets. This will especially be the case, when a relatively large proportion of the workforce is located outside core protected employment as in the Southern and Baltic countries. Combined with a lack of active labor market policies, such insider–outsider segmentation inhibits re-employment, especially into protected, high-quality jobs. The social consequences of unemployment may be particularly detrimental under these circumstances, resulting in enduring drops in satisfaction also after re-employment.

Concerning country compositional effects in the prevalence of unemployment, we expect that countries in which unemployment is relatively prevalent but of short duration, which is common in the liberal welfare regime, will show the lowest non-pecuniary costs of unemployment. This underlines the social meaning of unemployment as an important source for its long-term negative effects (Gangl, 2004). Unemployment may be less socially stigmatized if a relatively large proportion of the population experiences unemployment at some point in their life course and it is generally of short duration.

sec.title: Data, variables and methods
sec.p: The analysis is based on the EB 64.1 on geographic and labor market mobility (2005), including information on 23 European countries.5 For a descriptive introduction and analysis of external validity and data quality of the EB 64.1 see Vandenbrande et al. (2006). The question on job satisfaction is phrased as follows: ‘Generally speaking, when you think about your professional life, could you tell me whether you are very satisfied, fairly satisfied, fairly dissatisfied or not at all satisfied with each of the following . . .?’ Ten domains of job satisfaction were evaluated: satisfaction with salary, work contract, working hours, career prospects, commuting time, content of job, colleagues, training opportunities, work–life balance and health and safety conditions at the workplace. Job mobility is measured with an abbreviated life history design through a set of punctuated retrospective questions on the first and previous job, prospective questions on the current job, information about reasons for the last employer change and summary information about overall job mobility.6 The strengths of the EB 64.1 for our analysis lie in the large cross-country sample, the differentiated measure of job satisfaction and the detailed retrospective mobility information.7

sec.title: Dependent variables
sec.p: Global measures of overall job satisfaction might conceal complex dynamics between specific sub-domains of job satisfaction (Diener and Oishi, 2005). Out of the 10 job satisfaction domains, we choose three that represent theoretically grounded dimensions of job satisfaction, which we could empirically confirm in a factor analysis (iterated principal axis factoring, see Appendix Table A1). There were 10,905 persons currently employed (1627 self-employed and 9278 employed) who were asked the job satisfaction questions in the 23 countries we analyse. After excluding ‘don’t know’ answers there remained 8927 persons with answers on all 10 satisfaction domains. The job satisfaction domains that load highest on their respective factor and only load on a single factor are selected as dependent variables in the subsequent analysis: (1) satisfaction with work contract representing the dimension satisfaction with objective working conditions; (2) satisfaction with career prospects representing the dimension satisfaction with opportunities for career advancement; and (3) satisfaction with work–life balance representing the dimension satisfaction with combining work and private life.

Job satisfaction is recorded on a four-point scale from ‘very satisfied’ to ‘not at all satisfied’ in the EB 64.1. Figure 1 shows the distribution of the three ordinal outcome variables of job satisfaction by country and welfare state regime, excluding the ‘don’t know’ category: 7.1 percent of workers reported not to know how satisfied they are with their contract, 7.2 percent reported not to know their satisfaction with career prospects and 1.5 percent reported not to know how satisfied they are with their work–life balance. The countries within each welfare regime are sorted in descending order according to the share of very satisfied workers. In line with earlier findings (Kalleberg and Vaisey, 2005) reported satisfaction is generally high.

Satisfaction with work contract and career prospects varies more across welfare states than satisfaction with work–life balance. The Southern and post-socialist countries, particularly the CEE countries, show lower satisfaction with work contract and career prospects, in line with findings of low overall job satisfaction in Eastern European countries based on ISSP data (Gruenberg, 1980; Kahn, 1972).

sec.title: Job mobility indicators and control variables
sec.p: We include three sets of job mobility indicators: (1) characteristics of the most recent internal job change, (2) the most recent external job change and (3) overall mobility indicators over the past career.

We operationalize internal upward and downward mobility based on changes in required skill intensity in the current job compared to the previous job with the same employer. The question is phrased ‘Compared to the position you occupied when you started working for your current employer, does your current position require . . . same skills, more skills, less skills, or different skills?’ High skill intensity is generally related to higher pecuniary remuneration, better working conditions and better fringe benefits. Moreover, skill–job mismatches seem to be more relevant for job rewards than educational mismatches (Sousa-Poza and Sousa-Poza, 2000). Higher required skills in the current position compared to the previous position with the same employer indicate internal upward mobility; lower required skills indicate internal downward mobility.

External upward and downward mobility is operationalized as moves between occupations with the last employer change based on the International Standard Classification of Occupations 1988 (ISCO88). The ISCO88 provides a hierarchical classification of occupations based on skill level and skill specialization. The EU variant of ISCO88 implemented in the EB 64.1 comprises four skill levels based on the International Standard Classification of Education (ISCED), and on job-related formal training associated with the respective jobs (Allen and Van der Velden, 2001). It specifies nine major groups ranging from elementary occupations, such as laborers in construction, to senior officials and managers in the highest occupational group.8 A move between ISCO88 categories with the last employer change indicates external upward and downward mobility. Employer changes within one category of ISCO88 are considered a lateral external move. Whether the last employer change was voluntary or involuntary could also indicate external upward or downward moves. However, people may also find a better job after an involuntary employer change or accept downward moves voluntarily, if they prefer to work fewer hours or at a different location. We examine the impact of a voluntary job change separately from external upward and downward mobility. The EB 64.1 provides self-reported reasons for leaving the previous employer. We categorize a voluntary job change as the statements ‘found a better job’, ‘did not like previous job’, or ‘wanted to create own business’.

We include several overall mobility indicators. Unemployment enters the model as the number of unemployment spells of more than three months’ duration. The question is phrased: ‘Since you left your first job, how many times have you been without a job for more than three months? (Please do not include periods of paid or unpaid leave)’. We have no information about the exact length of the unemployment spells, but we can rule out search unemployment between education and first labor market entry. In addition, we account for job tenure with the current employer and total number of employer changes. Job tenure is informative about the most recent duration of ‘external stability’, while the number of employer changes indicates the overall quantity of external mobility.

We include perceived outside options as an additional mobility variable directed toward the future. High perceived outside options are measured as the reason ‘You think you will find a better job’ following the question ‘What would be the main reasons for you to change your current job (moving to another company) in the next five years?’ A first category ‘You don’t think you will change job in the next five years’ ensures that respondents only reported reasons if they believed they would change jobs within the next five years.

The EB 64.1 provides information on many known predictors of job satisfaction: individual motivations and values, current job characteristics and sociodemographic characteristics. Our first set of control variables includes the importance of four life domains that capture individual differences in motivation and values: importance of (1) employment and working conditions, (2) finances, (3) education and knowledge and (4) family and household. As characteristics of the current job we include working hours, type of contract, sector and occupation.9 We further control for gender, age, education, having children under the age of 10 in the household and living with a partner. Since job satisfaction ratings have an affective component (Elias and Birch, 1994) they can be influenced by the momentary mood of respondents at the time of the survey (Kalleberg, 1977). We include respondent cooperation during the interview (good or bad) as an indicator of affective state. Finally, we include welfare regime dummies and interactions between welfare regimes and unemployment. Table A2 in the Appendix shows descriptive statistics of all covariates.

We have observations on all covariates for 8533 individuals that can be included in the analysis. This corresponds to 78 percent of the 10,905 persons currently employed in the survey for the 23 countries we analyse. Missing values are most frequent for the question on unemployment, where we lose almost 11 percent of the cases. We excluded ‘don’t know’ answers in the satisfaction outcomes and therefore have slightly different total sample sizes in the models ranging between 8058 for satisfaction with career prospects and 8474 for satisfaction with work–life balance.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The outcomes are the ordinal satisfaction variables with four values. Basic ordinal regression relies on the parallel slopes assumption that the effect of the independent variables on each category of the ordinal outcome only differs in level, not in the slope, i.e. strength of association. Since the parallel slopes assumption is violated for a number of independent variables in our models, a common problem in ordinal regression, we estimate a generalized, partially constrained ordered logit model, also referred to as a partial proportional odds model for ordinal outcomes (Long and Freese, 2006). This model can take into account that some variables meet the parallel slopes assumption but others do not by constraining the beta coefficients for the variables that do not meet the parallel lines assumption (Williams, 2006). The crucial substantive advantage of the ordinal model over dichotomizing the ordinal satisfaction variables and modeling them with logistic regression is the possibility to assess whether satisfaction shifts slightly from ‘very satisfied’ to ‘fairly satisfied’ or if there is a drastic drop from ‘very satisfied’ to ‘not satisfied at all’ in response to job mobility (Fullerton, 2009; Williams, 2006).

Conceptually, ordinal regression assumes an underlying continuous outcome variable reflected by the ordinally measured dependent variable. Attitude ranges, such as satisfaction scales, collapsed into four or five categories have traditionally been a core field of application of these models. The generalized logit model can also be interpreted as a non-linear probability model that estimates the probability of each ordinal outcome category.

Given that our sample includes 23 countries, the assumption of independence of observations is likely violated, since they cluster within countries. With job satisfaction as the outcome of interest this is particularly serious, because national averages may function as reference levels for in-group comparisons. Thus, in addition to accounting for the moderating effect of welfare regimes, we implement robust standard errors by country to correct for intra-class correlations in the country clusters. All models are computed using a EU25 population weight. The effects are shown as marginal changes: a change in the probability to be satisfied as each independent variable changes by one unit, holding all other independent variables constant.

sec.title: Satisfaction with work contract
sec.p: Table 2 shows the partial proportional odds model on satisfaction with work contract. Neither hypothesis A on a greater impact of losses than gains, nor hypothesis B that internal mobility is more influential than external mobility are supported for satisfaction with contract. We find no effect for an internal downward move. An internal upward move slightly shifts the probability to be satisfied with one’s contract downward, with a 3.5 percent decrease to be ‘very satisfied’ and a 2 percent increase to be only ‘fairly satisfied’. This likely reflects higher expectations for work contract improvement with internal moves that are not met.

Instead, external mobility is decisive to improve satisfaction with work contract. External upward mobility shifts satisfaction levels in the upper range, with a 6.6 percent increase to be ‘very satisfied’ with one’s contract and 6.9 percent decrease to be only ‘fairly satisfied’. An external downward move shifts satisfaction levels downward in the middle range, with a 4.4 percent decrease to be ‘fairly satisfied’ and a 1.9 percent increase to be ‘fairly dissatisfied’. The probability to be satisfied with one’s contract further increases, if the last external job change was voluntary, particularly lowering the probability to be ‘not satisfied at all’.

The number of previous unemployment spells persistently lowers satisfaction with work contract in the current job across the full satisfaction range. This supports that unemployment is a ‘drastic career event’ that can lower satisfaction enduringly even after re-employment (hypothesis C). Each additional unemployment spell lowers the probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with one’s contract by 2.4 percent. However, unemployment only shifts satisfaction levels downward moderately with a 1.4 percent increase in the probability to be only ‘fairly satisfied’ and only a 0.2 percent increase in the probability to be ‘not satisfied at all’ with each additional unemployment spell.

Each additional year of job tenure increases the probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with one’s work contract. Apparently, longer tenure indeed comes with a subjectively better work contract, even though the last internal upward move does not increase satisfaction with work contract. This may reflect a selection effect, such that persons who are satisfied with their contract remain with the same employer for longer periods of time. Employees who believe that they will find a better job within the next five years have a 12.2 percent lower probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with their work contract. Similar to the negative effect of unemployment, these high perceived outside options rather shift very high satisfaction to moderate satisfaction and do not lead to outright dissatisfaction with work contract.

People in the Southern and Baltic welfare regime are less likely to be highly satisfied with their work contract than in the social-democratic countries. This suggests an interesting interaction between policies that foster strong insider–outsider segmentation, characteristic for OLMs, and country-specific labor force composition. Both the Southern and Baltic countries show strong insider–outsider segmentation paired with a relatively large proportion of employees outside the core protected workforce. In the Southern countries, e.g. Spain, this peripheral workforce is concentrated in an exceptionally large proportion of precarious temporary employment (Golsch, 2003). In the Baltic countries, existing EPL is often only weakly enforced or undermined by supplementary ‘extra agreements’ between employees and employers that place a large proportion of workers outside core protected employment (Saar et al., 2010). This combination of insider–outsider segmentation with a relatively large peripheral workforce could explain why we do not find lower satisfaction with contract for the corporatist countries that, similar to the social-democratic countries, also show strong insider–outsider segmentation but have a relatively larger core protected workforce and more rigidly enforced, stronger EPL.

The welfare regime interactions show that unemployment lowers satisfaction with work contract more in corporatist countries than in social-democratic countries. This is likely related to beneficial effects of the ‘flexicurity’ system in the social-democratic countries that facilitates re-employment to a greater extent than in the corporatist countries. Conversely, unemployment is less detrimental to satisfaction with work contract in the liberal and CEE countries. People who experience unemployment in the liberal and CEE welfare regimes maintain a higher probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with their work contract than in the social-democratic countries. This is arguably due to the higher overall prevalence of unemployment in the open employment relationships/ILMs in the liberal and CEE countries, even though welfare-sustaining policies in the event of unemployment are weaker than in the social-democratic countries. This suggests social stigma associated with unemployment as the driver of reduced satisfaction levels. Stigma related to unemployment is arguably lower, the more people in different segments of the labor market experience unemployment at some point in their career for relatively short durations.

sec.title: Satisfaction with career prospects
sec.p: Job mobility impacts satisfaction with career prospects quite differently than satisfaction with contract. This points to complex trade-offs between domain-specific job satisfaction in response to job mobility and underlines the importance of analysing job satisfaction domains separately (Tables 2 and 3). For satisfaction with career prospects, hypothesis A that the negative impact of downward moves exceeds the positive impact of upward moves is supported: internal downward moves induce a 9.5 percent decrease in the probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with career prospects, while internal upward moves increase the probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with career prospects by only 3.6 percent. In line with hypothesis B on the higher importance of internal mobility compared to external mobility, an external downward move has no significant effect, and the positive impact of an external upward move is small with a 1 percent increase to be ‘fairly satisfied’ with one’s career prospects. While external moves seem decisive to improve satisfaction with objective working conditions, such as work contract, internal moves are pivotal for satisfaction with future career prospects. An internal downward move violates expected gradual upward mobility, which is highly detrimental to one’s outlook on future career prospects. Both an external upward move and a voluntary external move induce an upward shift from very low satisfaction to being ‘fairly satisfied’, and thus seem to shield workers from strong dissatisfaction rather than leading to very high satisfaction with career prospects.

In support of hypothesis C, each additional unemployment spell decreases the probability to be ‘fairly satisfied’ or ‘very satisfied’ with career prospects by 0.9 and 1.7 percent, respectively. Conversely, unemployment increases the probability to be ‘not satisfied at all’ or ‘dissatisfied’ by a similar percentage. Analogous to satisfaction with contract, the probability to be satisfied with career prospects strongly decreases with high perceived outside options.

The post-socialist countries show lower satisfaction with career prospects than the social-democratic countries. This negative effect is particularly pronounced for the CEE countries with an 8 percent lower probability to be ‘very satisfied’ and a 5.7 percent higher probability to be ‘not satisfied at all’ compared to the social-democratic countries. It is also notable for the Baltic countries that show a 5.4 percent lower probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with one’s career prospects than the social-democratic countries. High labor market uncertainty related to the transition process in post-socialist countries may account for their lower satisfaction with career prospects. This finding is in line with the assumption that Western European countries serve as points of reference in the evaluation of job satisfaction in post-socialist countries.

The impact of unemployment on subsequent satisfaction with career prospects reflects individually perceived scar effects of unemployment for future career opportunities. The welfare regime interactions indicate particularly low individually perceived scar effects of unemployment in liberal welfare regimes with flexible labor markets and an overall relatively high prevalence of, often short-term, unemployment (DiPrete et al., 1997). People perceive unemployment as particularly detrimental for future career prospects in the Baltic countries. Apparently, the strong insider–outsider segmentation of labor markets in the Baltic countries combined with weak enforcement of existing EPL is particularly detrimental for satisfaction with future career prospects after unemployment.

sec.title: Satisfaction with work–life balance
sec.p: The model on satisfaction with work–life balance (Table 4) shows more pronounced differences from the models on satisfaction with work contract and career prospects and points to complex trade-offs in job satisfaction domains in response to job mobility.

Most notably, internal upward mobility comes at a cost of lower satisfaction with work–life balance. Internal upward moves induce a 3.6 percent decrease in the probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with one’s work–life balance. The negative effect of internal downward mobility is more pronounced with a 5.8 percent decrease in the probability to be ‘very satisfied’. Possibly, internal mobility to jobs with higher skill intensity initially requires more time investment, which burdens peoples’ work–life balance. People who moved downward in their last internal move may fear to be laid off in the future and react with increasing investment in their job to avoid unemployment, which is equally detrimental to their work–life balance. The negative effect of both internal upward and downward moves suggests potential work–life balance benefits from increasing tenure in the same job. Correspondingly, we find a non-linear effect for job tenure, such that tenure polarizes workers into being either ‘not satisfied at all’ or ‘fairly satisfied’ with their work–life balance. This suggests a polarization between long-tenure workers who are trapped in jobs that provide poor work–life balance, and workers who improve their work–life balance with increasing tenure. Again, we cannot rule out a selection effect such that workers who are satisfied with their work–life balance remain in their jobs for longer durations.

Similar to satisfaction with work contract, external upward moves are decisive to improve one’s work–life balance. External upward moves increase the probability to be highly satisfied with one’s work–life balance by 2.4 percent and decrease the probability to be ‘not at all satisfied’ by 0.3 percent. This suggests that only external moves empower workers to negotiate better objective working conditions and work–life balance improvements in their jobs, while internal moves remain important for the perception of future career opportunities. The effects of unemployment on satisfaction with work–life balance point in the hypothesized negative direction, but do not reach significance, possibly because country-specific effects cancel each other out, as suggested by the welfare regime interactions with unemployment discussed below. Analogous to the models on satisfaction with work contract and career prospects, high perceived outside options decrease the probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with one’s work–life balance with a sizable effect of 10.4 percent.

Compared to the social-democratic countries, people in the Southern and post-socialist countries are less likely to be ‘very satisfied’ with their work–life balance and more likely to be only ‘fairly satisfied’. This negative effect is most pronounced for the Southern welfare regime with a 15.1 percent lower probability to be ‘very satisfied’ with one’s work–life balance than in the social-democratic countries, but also sizable in the CEE and Baltic countries with a 14.4 and 11.9 percent decrease. This is in line with findings of high levels of work–family conflict in Southern countries (Saar et al., 2010). In post-socialist transition economies, families frequently rely on two earners for living maintenance, which collides with a lack of adequate family policy support and workplace flexibility (Drobnič and Fratczak, 2001; Glass and Fodor, 2007; Parent-Thirion et al., 2007; Róbert et al., 2001) This compositional structure of dual earner families and weak provisions in family policies seem to generate similarly high levels of work–family conflict in the post-socialist countries as in the Southern countries.

Compared to the social-democratic countries, unemployment is more detrimental to subsequent work–life balance in the corporatist and Southern welfare regime. Weak childcare infrastructure, rigid insider–outsider labor markets and high social stigma of unemployment in these countries likely account for these effects.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This article addressed two questions: (1) which types of job mobility affect domain-specific job satisfaction and (2) do welfare state regimes alter the relationship between job mobility and job satisfaction? Based on a discussion of sociological and economic theories on job satisfaction and insights from the psychology of well-being, our empirical analyses rest on the assumption that the impact of job mobility on job satisfaction is domain-specific and varies by welfare regimes. We hypothesized that downward mobility will be more powerful than upward mobility (hypothesis A), internal mobility will matter more than external mobility (hypothesis B) and unemployment as a ‘drastic’ career event can enduringly lower job satisfaction (hypothesis C).

After controlling for welfare regime differences,hypotheses A and B are supported only for satisfaction with career prospects. Hypothesis C on the negative impact of unemployment is supported across welfare regimes for satisfaction with work contract and career prospects, and for the corporatist and Southern countries for satisfaction with work–life balance. Unemployment is not just a search process but a ‘drastic’ career event that can enduringly lower subsequent satisfaction at the workplace, above and beyond changing job rewards and welfare regime differences (‘net mobility effect’). These findings are in line with revisions of the hedonic treadmill model.

Our findings point toward complex trade-offs between job satisfaction domains as predicted in the life cycle hypothesis. This is highlighted by the differential impact of internal and external mobility on domain-specific job satisfaction. External upward mobility is pivotal to enhance satisfaction with objective working conditions and work–life balance, while internal upward mobility – in particular the avoidance of internal downward moves – is decisive for satisfaction with future career prospects. This suggests that European workers primarily succeed in negotiating better contractual conditions that provide better objective working conditions and less work–life conflict with external mobility. Further, complex trade-offs may exist within satisfaction domains, for instance between satisfaction with work contract and satisfaction with salary, which both represent ‘satisfaction with objective working conditions’. On the one hand, people may accept lower salaries in exchange for the higher job security of a permanent contract. On the other hand, salary and types of work contract may cluster at the bottom and top of the skill distribution, such that low-skilled workers have precarious work contracts and low salaries and high-skilled workers receive both high salaries and favorable work contracts. Future research should further investigate such trade-offs in job satisfaction domains.

Despite the stability of job mobility effects across welfare regimes, welfare regimes do spur their own dynamics in the processes that determine job satisfaction. Our results support the argument that social policies and country compositional effects interact to determine job satisfaction. This is visible, for instance, in the lower satisfaction with work contract in the Southern and Baltic countries, where strong insider–outsider segmentation goes along with a workforce composition where large proportions of the workforce are located in unprotected peripheral employment. We did not find such a negative effect for the corporatist countries, in which strong insider–outsider segmentation is paired with a relatively more sizable core protected workforce.

The individually perceived scar effects of unemployment for career prospects are lowest in liberal countries, characterized by open employment relationships. The on average higher prevalence but shorter duration of unemployment and higher overall mobility levels in flexible liberal labor markets may render unemployment more transitory and less socially stigmatized. This supports the social meaning of unemployment as an important source of long-term non-pecuniary costs of unemployment. Possibly, unemployment is only a ‘drastic’ career event as long as it is experienced by a relatively small proportion of the population; it stigmatizes (Solga, 2002) and frequently results in downward spirals of recurrent unemployment. If transitory unemployment becomes more frequent as a short-term phenomenon that affects large proportions of the population at some point in their life course, and mostly leads to quick re-employment on a similar level, it may no longer lead to enduring drops in satisfaction.

A limitation of our study is that we cannot rule out selection effects, since we cannot compare satisfaction levels after labor market moves to individual baselines of satisfaction. We can, however, control for many important determinants of job satisfaction and ensured temporal precedence of job mobility through the abbreviated life history design of the EB 64.1. In a study on life satisfaction based on several European data sources (Layard et al., 2007), the partial relationship between reported happiness and log income proved highly stable in panel data, cross-sectional and pooled cross-sectional data, strengthening confidence in our findings based on the Eurobarometer 64.1. Our results demonstrate the added value of a differentiated domain-specific measure of job satisfaction, data that are so far not available on the European level in comparable detail. Future research should additionally address the dynamics of both job satisfaction and job mobility based on prospective panel data to further enhance our knowledge about how job mobility actually makes people happy in their jobs.

In concluding, we return to our starting point of the added value of studying subjective outcomes of economic processes. Why should we care about soft outcomes such as satisfaction with work contract instead of measuring type of contract directly? Beyond an intrinsic interest in satisfaction and happiness as desirable objectives in life, the growing attention these soft outcomes have drawn in the social sciences is anchored in an old utilitarian tradition. Satisfaction and happiness are increasingly accepted as valid measures of subjective utility that are distinct from objective rewards and need to be studied separately (Frey and Stutzer, 2002b; Layard, 2005). For instance, per capita income has steadily increased in most developed democracies across the past decades, while happiness has decreased or remained stable. Linking back to the tradition of utilitarianism, proponents of happiness research advocate the maximization of citizens’ happiness as the ultimate goal for social policy (e.g. Layard, 2005; Veenhoven, 1993) and job satisfaction plays a prominent role in overall happiness in European countries.

We cannot rule out problems of unobserved heterogeneity, because we do not have repeated measurement points. Unmeasured variation across individuals may affect both mobility and job satisfaction independently from each other, and anticipated job satisfaction may determine job mobility. A strategy to alleviate reversed causation is the inclusion of an instrumental variable (see Le Grand and Tåhlin, 2002 for an application to job mobility). Instrumental variables, however, are quite controversial. Because the error term is by definition unobservable, there is no way to formally prove that an instrumental variable is uncorrelated to the error of the dependent variable. Poor instruments come at a high cost, since they introduce additional bias. Lacking a convincing instrument, this approach is not a feasible solution for our analysis.
